title: Russian Grand Prix 2019: What time does the F1 race start, what TV channel is it on and what are the latest odds?
text:
The Sochi Autodrom has hosted the Russian Grand Prix since 2014 - REUTERS

What is it?

The 2019 Russian Grand Prix at the Sochi Autodrom, the 16th race of the 2019 Formula One season.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

When is it?

The first two practice sessions take place on Friday September 27, qualifying runs on Saturday September 28 and the race itself is on Sunday September 29.

What time does it start?

Qualifying starts at 1pm BST but the race begins at 12.10pm BST on Sunday.

What TV channel is it on?

Sky Sports F1 have exclusive coverage rights in the UK this year and indeed for the next few. Qualifying coverage begins at 12pm BST and race coverage begins at 10.30am BST on Sunday.

Channel 4 have highlights for this round, too. Their qualifying program begins at 6.30pm BST on Saturday with their race coverage starting at 6pm BST on Sunday.

You can also keep up to date throughout the race with Luke Slater right here at Telegraph Sport.

Watch the Russian Grand Prix through Now TV for £9.99.

What do we know about the Sochi Autodrom?

Circuit length: 5.848km

First grand prix: 2014

Laps: 53

Race distance: 309.745km

Race lap record: 1:35.861 (Valtteri Bottas, 2018)

2018 winner: Lewis Hamilton, Mercedes

Number of corners: 18

Overtaking chances: Well, reasonable I guess, with the couple of heavy braking zones. It's also quite a wide track in places and, if you get a good exit out of the right turn two, the long, long, long 180-degree turn three gives you a chance to go around the outside.

What happened last year?

Lewis Hamilton had his luckiest victory of the year. Valtteri Bottas outclassed him all weekend but was told by his team to move over when leading to that Hamilton could maximise his championship points total. He was not very happy about it.

What are the odds (top six)?

Story continues

Lewis Hamilton 7/4

Charles Leclerc 15/8

Sebastian Vettel 11/4

Valtteri Bottas 5/1

Max Verstappen 25/1

Alexander Albon 100/1

What is our prediction?

Bottas is the boss at this track (well, were he not asked to make way for Hamilton last year...) and has never been out-qualified by a team-mate. He took his maiden victory here in 2017 and should have won last year, too. Mercedes have never been beaten here, either. But with Ferrari's surprisingly good performance in Singapore they could put up a fight here, too. It will be the true test of their upgrades. We think they will be close, but not quite close enough to stop one Mercedes winning. Which one? Hamilton.

Podium prediction: 1st Hamilton 2nd Leclerc 3rd Bottas
